item.title: Hubble will change how it points, but NASA says 'great science' will continue
item.description: NASA is shifting the way the Hubble Space Telescope points. The change is a work-around for a piece of hardware that's become intolerably glitchy. Officials say Hubble will continue to do 'ground breaking science,' for about another decade.
item.content:encoded:

(Image credit: NASA)

item.title: The NAACP calls on American Airlines to investigate recent discrimination incidents
item.description: Derrick Johnson, president of the NAACP, says that without an appropriate response from American Airlines, the civil rights organization will be forced to reinstate an advisory against the airline.

item.title: Modi has declared victory in India's election, but not the landslide he expected
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has won a third term, but voters drastically clipped his wings by handing his alliance a narrower margin than predicted.

item.title: A beleaguered breeder faces a record $35 million fine for mistreating its beagles
item.description: The companies behind the now-closed Virginia facility pleaded guilty to violating the Animal Welfare Act and Clean Water Act. Animal rights groups applaud the development and say there's more to do.

item.title: Shohei Ohtani's ex-interpreter pleads guilty to charges related to gambling and theft
item.description: Ippei Mizuhara, who worked alongside Ohtani for years, pleaded guilty to two counts related to the theft of nearly $17 million from the baseball star. He could face up to 33 years in prison.

item.title: After saying Charlotte, a lone stingray, was pregnant, aquarium now says she's sick
item.description: Charlotte the ray was touted as a case of asexual reproduction. Her aquarium now says she's actually sick with a rare disease — not pregnant. "This is a very weird story," an expert tells NPR.

item.title: A family fled Rafah as the war closed in. Now they're living in a bombed-out school
item.description: A classroom in a bombed-out school has become a shelter for an extended family of 20 Palestinians. They fled Rafah after Israel's latest offensive in the southern Gaza city.
